document:
Malware – Viruses
One of the two most common types of malware
Designed to replicate and spread
Usually spreads through email
Uses system resources and causes network slowdowns or stoppage

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Malware – Trojan Horses
Another common type of malware
Named after the wooden horse of ancient history
Appears benign but downloads malware onto a computer from within

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Malware – Spyware and Logic Bombs
Spyware is rapidly growing
Cookies
Key loggers
Logic bombs – lay dormant until a condition is met (e.g. a date)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Types of Hackers
White Hat – authorized to find and fix vulnerabilities
Black Hat – non-ethical hacking for malicious gain
Grey Hat – hack without malicious intent but often without permission

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Basic Security Terminology
Devices:
• Firewall – filters network traffic
• Proxy server – disguises internal host IP
• Intrusion Detection System – monitors traffic for attacks
Activities:
• Authentication
• Auditing

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Exercise – Respond During an Intrusion
Scenario: Your PC responds slowly; gateway shows high network activity though no network apps are open.
• What types of malware could cause these symptoms?
• How might it have gained access?
• What steps can confirm infection?
• If malware is confirmed, how do you restore safe operation?

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
In-Class Exercise – Responses
• Likely malware: virus, worm
• Access method: phishing email or malicious link/attachment
• Check logs, antivirus reports, or use Wireshark to inspect traffic
• Identify abnormal destinations or services in use

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Restoring Safe Operation
• Isolate infected machine from networks
• Attempt data backup (may include infected files)
• Rebuild system or recover from clean backup
• If no backup: try antivirus cleanup
• Moral: plan ahead, know risks, maintain backups and insurance

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Cybersecurity Definition (NIST 7298)
“Measures and controls ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information-system assets including hardware, software, firmware, and information being processed, stored, and communicated.”
Key questions:
1. What assets need protection?
2. How are they threatened?
3. What countermeasures are appropriate?

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
CIA Triad (Information Assurance)
Confidentiality – prevent unauthorized disclosure
Integrity – ensure data and systems change only as authorized
Availability – ensure systems operate promptly and reliably for authorized users

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Security Goals and Threats
• Confidentiality loss → Disclosure of sensitive data
• Integrity loss → Unauthorized modification or destruction
• Availability loss → Denial of service to legitimate users

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Types of Attacks
• Passive – eavesdropping on communications (traffic analysis, data interception)
• Active – modifying or disrupting communication (stream modification, DoS, spoofing)

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Attack Surfaces and Attack Trees
• Attack surface – all points where an adversary can try to enter or extract data
• Attack tree – hierarchical representation of possible attack paths to a goal
Used for threat modeling and defense prioritization.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Threat Modeling
• Identify assets
• Determine potential threats and vulnerabilities
• Estimate risk and impact
• Prioritize mitigation strategies

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Fundamental Security Design Principles
1. Least Privilege
2. Fail-Safe Defaults
3. Economy of Mechanism
4. Complete Mediation
5. Open Design
6. Separation of Privilege
7. Least Common Mechanism
8. Psychological Acceptability

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Case Study – Manufacturing System
• Attack surface includes controllers, sensors, and remote connections
• Threats: malware, supply-chain tampering, insider manipulation
• Mitigations: network segmentation, access control, integrity checks

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Case Study – Special Education Applications
• Sensitive student data requires strict confidentiality
• Threats: improper access controls, phishing, ransomware
• Mitigations: encryption, user training, secure backups

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Packet Sniffing and Spoofing
• Sniffing – capturing network traffic (e.g., Wireshark)
• Spoofing – faking source addresses to mislead targets
• Both common in network attacks and defense testing

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)
• Monitor traffic for malicious activity
• Signature-based and anomaly-based methods
• Examples: Snort, Suricata
• Complement to firewalls and antivirus

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Legal and Ethical Issues
• Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA)
• Privacy laws and data-protection regulations
• Ethical responsibility of security professionals
• Penetration-testing authorization requirements

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 1.pptx

document:
Review Questions

2. How do attack surfaces and threat models differ?

4. Why is least privilege important?

• Threat modeling and attack trees aid risk assessment
• CIA Triad guides design and policy
• Ethical hacking and IDS are key defenses
